importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article reports on the latest developments in OpenAI’s Sora 2 platform, including new policies announced on this date in response to industry concerns from Hollywood studios, unions, and talent agencies.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeline spans from last year’s California legislation (signed by Governor Gavin Newsom) to the current developments in 2025, indicating a growing trend of legal and ethical scrutiny around AI-generated content involving real people and characters.

keyTakeAways: OpenAI has introduced new policies for its AI tool Sora 2 in response to widespread criticism from Hollywood talent agencies and unions over unauthorized use of real people's likenesses.
AI-generated videos of historical figures like Martin Luther King Jr., Robin Williams, and Michael Jackson doing things they never did have raised serious ethical and legal concerns.
The daughter of Robin Williams, Zelda, publicly criticized the AI-generated content as 'horrible slop' and 'disgusting, over-processed hotdogs' made from real human lives.

Hollywood talent agencies including United Talent Agency and Creative Artists Agency, along with SAG-AFTRA, have called for stronger protections and consent mechanisms, leading to support for federal legislation called the 'NO FAKES Act'.
OpenAI has implemented an 'opt-in' policy allowing individuals to control whether their likeness can be simulated, and will remove content that violates consent or intellectual property rights.

Existing AI-generated videos featuring copyrighted characters like SpongeBob SquarePants have been flagged as infringing on intellectual property, prompting action from the Motion Picture Association.
SAG-AFTRA’s national executive director Duncan Crabtree-Ireland emphasized that without consent, AI technology poses a systemic risk to creative industries and individual rights.

summaryOfNewsArticle: OpenAI has introduced new policies for its AI video tool Sora 2 following intense backlash from Hollywood studios, unions, and talent agencies over unauthorized AI-generated content featuring real people and copyrighted characters. Videos depicting Martin Luther King Jr., Robin Williams, Michael Jackson, and even the CEO of OpenAI have been criticized as disrespectful, exploitative, and dehumanizing. Performers and their families, including Robin Williams’ daughter Zelda, have condemned such content as a violation of human dignity and artistic integrity. Talent agencies like United Talent Agency and Creative Artists Agency, along with the union SAG-AFTRA, have urged OpenAI to implement strict consent mechanisms, leading to support for the federal 'NO FAKES Act' to require permission before using digital replicas. OpenAI has responded by introducing an opt-in policy, blocking public generation of well-known characters, and removing non-compliant content, including videos of Martin Luther King Jr. and SpongeBob SquarePants. These developments reflect a growing ethical and legal debate about AI, consent, and the rights of performers in the age of artificial intelligence.
title: Hollywood Pushes OpenAI for Consent
